comments.commentBody: That is the hollywood ending.

The risk of company bankruptcy led to the Pension Guarantee fund to ensure that employees of bankrupt companies don't lose their payments. All companies pay a small contribution, and the risk of bankruptcy is thus spread across all employees, rather than a few. Lately, between the overall decline of defined benefit plans, and ruthless gaming of the fund to advance corporate self-interest, the fund is (surprise!) underfunded. The problem is that our political system is very bad at protecting long-term interests of the politically disempowered when these conflict with the short-term interests of the highly empowered.

Many public defined benefit plans are constitutionally guaranteed in states, and states can't go bankrupt. But in the public sphere, there was also gaming -- often by public employers who chose to give exorbitant pension benefits to the more powerful unions (often at the expense of less powerful public employees), leading to underfunding as well.

Defined benefit plans sure aren't perfect. But one feature that they have, if properly established, is that they serve as insurance as well as savings: a good deal of risk that individuals face in defined contribution pension plans is turned into collective or even socialized risk. And for lower-income employees, that's a big deal and very good thing, which defined benefit plans have not yet managed to address systematically.

There was a nytimes article 5  years ago (I cannot find it now) that offered the stats on NYC murders and how many are "solved" versus unsolved.  Something like 20% of crimes officially declared as murder (with a body found) are never ever solved by the NYPD.  So there's lots of folks getting away with murder in NYC, wealthy or not. Not a happy thought but closer to the truth about people like Mr Durst than we comfortably like to think about.

Holding bonds to maturity eliminates price fluctuation risk...but not inflation risk (which price fluctuations simply track in real time, rather than waiting until the bond matures).

Given the prospect of a number of years of low inflation looking forward, bonds provide some safety. TIPS protect, over the long term, from inflation risk, too, at the expense of lower current returns.

The more general problem is that the increasing financialization of all forms of investment means that all are more subject to rapid and large fluctuation.

8D Definition is Piece of women's clothing, rest is the cryptic part. 14A Bust is the definition. I'm being presumptuous to disagree with the cluing but "say"isn't necessary. I think it misdirects as it suggests an auditory clue. I'm glad you are joining us on the cryptic trail. Yes, the Aha! moments are great.

Is this real life or entertainment? Seriously. I've felt it coming for sometime, and I think we're there:  Life imitates art. Even Jihadi John now has a gloss of celebrity that might fly in a reality TV market (though as the bad guy, of course).

Well, since we blacks are so sure the judicial system is biased against us, maybe we should stay on the right side of the law.

There's no reason to commit a crime just because good opportunities are lacking in certain communities.

It's not Robert Durst's fault that poor blacks can't afford top notch attorneys.

What was astounding was the sheer incompetence and sloth-like pursuit of justice as displayed by the initial New York detective. In the series, he played like a Serpico-era NYC cop cliche that really couldn't be bothered, willing to take whatever Durst declared as gospel, and generally acted--even decades later--like he was killing time till the Yankees game began.

If he had done his job to begin with, Durst wouldn't have been able to carry his roadshow murder act to Texas and California.
Durst is a grown up.  He can take off his own microphone.  He can also keep his mouth shut.
I hope the producers of Serial are taking notes on how to properly wrap up a docuthriller. Once again, Television slays Radio - as if it were a fair fight.
He's a chilling character to be sure, and the Texas decision was a joke.   Still, I don't hear his bathroom rambling and "killed them all, of course" as a rock-solid confession for the court.
Apparently the second interview was over two years ago but the producers say they only discovered the bathroom recording recently.
Oh please. He's a public figure, who initiated this documentary. What he said on the tape is, to say the least, newsworthy.
It wasn't secret - he forgot he was wearing a mic, that's all.
They need more than the envelope. The "confession" certainly helps too.

Did you watch Episode Six? The forensic analyst looked at several other pieces of Durst writing, all with the same block letters - including a lease agreement where he had a fake name. The analyst agreed that all this writing points to the same person.
That actually is how you spell Berkeley, though...unless you mean that people mistakenly spell it as Berkley?

"Reasonable doubt" could certainly be forged by a skilled defense team. The letter could have been a setup, created by someone with a sample of his block printing. The misspelled "Beverley" is a commonly botched word, not unlike "Berkeley." Alternately, the real killer might even have had a copy of one of his letters with the misspelling included. Any strange behavior demonstrated in the interview would be the natural product of being shown such compelling evidence .. his bathroom "confession" a mere replaying of the interviewer-subject exchange. Why, after all, would Durst consent to be part of the production if he had something to hide?

All said, he seems like a guilty man in need of narcissistic feed .. but this carries little weight in a court of law.

IONICally believe that PEEWEEREESE couldn't possibly fail as a major league ballplayer, simply because he was always totally at E's, both at bat and in the field!

Ian Livengood certainly deserves a RIMshot for this tasty "Little" TREAT he served up for our MONXWDP solving pleasure!

EWERS TIL the STARs lose their Glory...

Gasser and Dukan, seniors at Wisconsin, visited my daughter's second grade classroom to read books during "literacy week." Badger football and basketball players visit sick kids in the cancer ward throughout the regular season. (JJ Watt was a regular when he attended.) Most UW players are midwest kids, going to school like any other, but with athletic talent that leads to local celebrity, something many take pride in for good causes.

Maybe it's not the same everywhere, but I think you are unfair to stereotype all scholar athletes based on what you've heard or seen about a few. In fact, the way you've belittled thousands of young men and women and their millions of fans is shamefully arrogant and anti-social.

We have actually gotten to know Willie Cauley-Stein pretty well after three years (he's a junior and has played in at least 60+ games over the past two years), the Harrison twins and Dakari Johnson and others after two. I do hope Tyler Ulis--the smallest man on the team--will stay for awhile. Scoring used to be much higher in the Dean Smith days when there was such a thing as a "touch" foul and basketball wasn't a contact sport. Well, except of course, Smith was not noted for teams with lightning speed. Whatever the flaws of the "one and done," I can't say that I regret the time John Wall and Anthony Davis spent playing college ball, or blame them for getting on with it.

Villanova and Wisconsin use the full clock.  Nobody know anyone on Kentucky since they are just passing though.  Duke is intolerable because they're Duke, though Okafor is definitely worth watching.  There will be a lot of methodical basketball.  Which is good.  Because baseball is around the corner and college ball will make baseball seem fast-paced.

What is the case Barbara here? Hardly it makes sense.

If the argument is it is the common public which generates "data" in captive networks of these companies which churn it further and then 'sale' by bundling it another form; there can be some merit to that. But not whole - since participation in digitized transactions orchestrated by these Valley companies is completely voluntary.

The larger problem with this criticism as well as of Gurley's argument is; both are conveniently forgetting that lot many other start-ups in Valley are not linked with Social Networking.

Spot on about the medical widgets.  One area to keep on eye on is the medical widget sold as a medical service.  If insurers make a bunch of silly medical widgets available to their customers the via the Internet they can claim they met the considerations of the MLR provision of the ACA.  Trouble is if their customers don't have access to the Internet it hardly seems reasonable to claim the company is putting 80% of its premiums towards medical care.  Hopefully, some dedicated folks will keep an eye on this shameful situation and plan their audits accordingly.  Insurers don't want to issue reimbursements.

Well at some point in time maybe "real" valuations might return as all these services do is connect a bunch of algorithms and Uber does one step beyond in providing a service, but you wouldn't like it if you didn't have a choice of Uber or a cab either. Both can and should exist in harmony.

The Data selling business is pretty killing innovation as way too many are into collecting data and selling it with no concern for us, the producers of the data. We needs to index and license them as it's a greedy world and so much of this is driving what some call innovation and this goes to include some mHealth and Fintech apps by all means.

Time to look at the "Techno Gods" and their proprietary code that makes money and let some others replicate their formulas for accuracy as some are really pushing the envelope and duping consumers.

I was in Carolina when Valvano was there.  You way understate the local affection, which is disrespectful, all things considered, and is indicative of why Duke is a Carolina outsider.
Keta, the energy, the joy, the commitment and the value you bring to this Blog is amazing.

I tried for years to find a local artist to do our home watercolor. Went to art fairs. Posted at a local art center. Nope. The artist I used through etsy is from my state but several hours away. This is her " gig" but I'd gave never gave found her any other way

Kudos to Mr. Jarecki and Mr. Smerling. They took an opportunity, presented by the same sociopath that created it, and ran with it. Their instinctive ability to go back to the beginning of the story and see it through with all it's graphic detail provided the information required to bring a serial killer to justice. I promise you, Mr. Durst regrets the day he contacted them. But yet, that's exactly what feeds into his ego/sociopathic nature. To see the details of a man on the run for murder in Texas and yet still feels justified to steal a sandwich in Pennsylvania, while having over $38k on him mind you, exposes a man who feels the laws of society simply do not apply to him. Robert Durst can't help but remind me of Lance Armstrong. Not that Lance Armstrong is a killer but the fact that if he would of just left well enough alone? He most likely would of got away with the crime. I certainly hope the DA's of New York and most likely California do not drop the ball this time. If they have any questions/doubts simply refer back to this brilliant documentary created by Mr. Jarecki and Mr. Smerling.
Sounds a little like Rumplestiltskin's dance in the woods.
More importantly - the handwriting matches regardless of whether the latrine mumblings are admissible in court. Say goodnight, bob.
That's exactly right.
sixmile, don't be too sure, remember Texas? The prosectors thought they had a slam dunk.

Here's what he said to himself at the end. I'm sure his attorneys will say he was imagining how it might look to others:
"There it is.
You’re caught
You’re right of course.
But you can’t imagine.
Arrest him.
I don’t know what’s in the house.
Oh, I want this.
What a disaster.
He was right.
I was wrong.
And the burping.
I’m having difficulty with the question.
What the hell did I do?
Killed them all, of course."
